Tesco used its meeting with analysts and investors to drop one of Clarke's big pledges – a profit margin target of 5.2% which, despite its recent problems, remained the highest in the industry. Finance director Laurie McIlwee stopped short of spelling it out but in front of a slide carrying the bullet point "£ not % is the measure of margin success" he said in the future "cash not percentage margin would define our success".

Getting rid of the target in effect signals a willingness to make less profit on its sales as it tries to win back disgruntled shoppers with price cuts and promotions. Analysts have trimmed their profit forecasts for this year with trading profits of £3.3bn pencilled in compared with £3.5bn in 2012-13.

Clarke conceded the headline numbers were "not where we want them to be" and that he had not moved fast enough. "I have never seen such a pace of change in my 40 years at Tesco," he said. "We didn't change enough – not enough for our customers at least."

Analysts had argued that the margin figure was a "straitjacket" at a time when its prices were out of kilter with the competition. To that end Tesco announced a £200m price cuts scheme focused on staple groceries. "Our prices must get better and be more stable," said Clarke. Asda immediately responded with its own £100m of price cuts.

Clarke has tried price cuts to win back customers before – its £500m Price Drop campaign in 2011. On Tuesday he said that campaign "wasn't executed particularly well"

Clarke, a Tesco lifer, is two years into a £1bn turnaround plan for the UK chain, with store refurbishments, extra staff on the shop floor and promotions. To date Tesco has refurbished 615 of its near 2,600 UK estate and has promised to spend £500m a year for the next three years to finish the job by 2017.

Clarke said: "We have spent the last two years strengthening the foundations of our business. There was a lot to do." Clarke added that he was trying to improve pricing, quality and service, but that it was "taking more time than we thought it would".

The initiatives failed to win over shoppers at Christmas with like-for-like sales down 2.4% in the six weeks to 4 January.

Clarke slammed the brakes on the group's physical expansion two years ago when it became clear the growing popularity of online and convenience stores threatened to turn its more than 200 out-of-town hypermarkets into white elephants.

Over many years it had amassed a vast land bank to build stores, but the about-turn in shoppers' habits forced it to write down its value by £800m last year, in effect admitting it would never build on many of the sites.

Heralding an era of more conservative physical growth, the chain told investors that its annual capital expenditure would not exceed £2.5bn for the next three years. Last year it spent £3bn – which was down sharply from a high of £6.6bn in 2008.

Like other supermarket groups, Tesco's biggest stores have fast become millstones. Clarke has been trying to make Tesco's sprawling Extra stores more attractive by introducing restaurants – it bought the Giraffe chain for £49m in 2013 – as well as soft play areas and even nail bars. After a series of trials around the country Clarke said Tesco had now come up with a winning formula for its big stores and these ideas would be introduced across the chain.

Tesco will continue to expand its convenience chain Tesco Express at a rate of 150 stores a year. The other main focus is its website, where plans include subscription services and one-hour home delivery slots for time-poor shoppers.

Clarke is concentrating on the UK chain which, given it generates two-thirds of Tesco's profits, underpins its success. To that end he has struck a series of deals to eliminate distraction caused by problem businesses in Japan, the US and China. At the start of this week Tesco confirmed it was seeking to restructure its struggling Turkish chain Kipa. In a statement to the Istanbul stock exchange, it said it was "in talks with various companies regarding various options".

Tesco shares, 400p when Clarke took over the top job in March 2011, closed up 1.8p at 335p.

Bryan Roberts at Kantar Retail said Tesco had made some "reassuring noises", but he added: "Simply lowering prices will not be enough to counter the steady advance of the discounters. One of the reasons that Aldi is thriving [is] economy of time and complexity. Shoppers don't just want cheap, they also want quick and easy.

"Secondly, the fact that most retailers price-match each other means that price is increasingly irrelevant within the supermarket industry. This means that differentiation through quality and service is more important than ever – and I'm not sure that today's revelations mean that Tesco is significantly closer to achieving that."
fields.trailText: Philip Clarke drops profit margin target to win back custom as analysts trim earnings forecasts to £3.3bn

webTitle: Housebuilder's profits and mortgage approvals soar on back of Help to Buy

fields.standfirst: Persimmon reports surge in pre-tax profits by 49% to £330m in year to end of December and mortgage approvals rise 57%
fields.body:
Britain's second biggest housebuilder has revealed a surge in annual profit after the government's Help to Buy scheme fuelled demand for new homes and helped send mortgage approvals to their highest level in almost 6½ years.

Persimmon said underlying pre-tax profit jumped 49% to £330m in the year to the end of December – near the top end of City forecasts. The first few weeks of this year's crucial spring selling season went well, it added.

The company said sale completions rose by 16% to 11,528 and the average selling price increased 4% to £181,861. Forward sales, which are agreed but not completed, were up 41% to £1.4bn.

Meanwhile the British Bankers' Association reported just under 50,000 mortgage approvals for house purchases in January, worth £8bn.

The number was up 57% on a year earlier. It was the highest number of home loans since September 2007, before the financial crisis took hold, and further evidence of Britain's strengthening housing market.

On a monthly basis the number of approvals was 6% higher than in December, marking an 11th successive monthly increase. Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, said the figures would "fuel concern that we are on the way to a new housing bubble".

"While the strength of house prices is not yet a serious concern outside of London, it is something that needs to be closely monitored given that a number of recent data and surveys have indicated that the strength in house prices is becoming more widespread," he added.

The UK housing market has strengthened in recent months amid growing consumer confidence, rising employment, low interest rates, a lack of properties on the market, and the taxpayer-backed boost from Help to Buy.

The average price of a home hit £250,000 in December, according to figures published by the Office for National Statistics last week.

Persimmon's strong results follow similarly buoyant figures from Bovis Homes on Monday, as housebuilders reap the rewards of less stringent lending by banks and rising house prices. More listed housebuilders – Taylor Wimpey, Barratt and Redrow – report this week.

As a result of booming business, Persimmon said it would return cash to shareholders more quickly than planned. It will pay out a dividend of 70p in July this year with further early payments in 2016 and 2018 that would originally have been paid in 2021.

Britain's housebuilders have been the main beneficiaries of government schemes to unblock the mortgage market. Persimmon said it had sold 4,250 new homes to customers using Help to Buy and that 2,203 of those legally completed in 2013.

Nicholas Wrigley, Persimmon's chairman, said: "Persimmon achieved a strong result for the year as we responded quickly to the increased customer demand that resulted from improved mortgage lending, the introduction of Help to Buy in April 2013 and the increase in consumer confidence as the UK returned to more meaningful economic growth.

"The group entered 2014 with a very strong forward order book and the early weeks of the spring selling season have been encouraging. We anticipate a further year of encouraging sales growth in 2014."

Persimmon shares have risen almost 40% since the end of September. The shares closed down 0.5% at £14.63.

webTitle: Justin King: 'Sainsbury's will go from strength to strength'

fields.standfirst: Departing supermarket chief says he expects business to outperform rivals despite increasing competition in industry
fields.body:
Justin King has insisted he is not bailing out of Sainsbury's before the supermarket hits tough times, despite admitting that the grocery market had changed forever.

"A lot of commentators said it was a good time to leave back in 2007/8 after we effected the turnaround of Sainsbury's. But in the five or six years since then Sainsbury's, by any measure, has been the most successful of the grocers. There's no reason at all that the business shouldn't go from strength to strength," said King, who steps down as chief executive of the British supermarket this summer.

Speaking at the National Farmers Union conference King said there was "no going back" to a world before the major supermarkets faced competition both from discounters and upmarket grocers such as Waitrose. But he played down the potential for a supermarket price war despite the rise of Aldi and Lidl, and new price cuts announced by Asda and Tesco.

"If price was the driving force (behind the growth of the discounters) then shoppers could come and shop the Sainsbury's Basics range and save more than at a discounter. The whole conversation about discounters is misrepresented. The driving force of growth is more stores in more accessible locations," King said.

He said Sainsbury's had been able to outperform its major rivals throughout the downturn, despite charging more for its own label goods than some competitors, because shoppers continued to be interested in quality and the provenance of food.

That assertion was born out by a National Farmers Union survey which revealed that public trust in supermarkets had sunk to 52%, down from 69% ahead of the horsemeat scandal which rocked the industry last year.

King said it would take "many many years" for the industry to regain the levels of trust it formerly enjoyed. Sainsbury's has benefited from the fact that no horsemeat was found in any of its products, but King said even his company would take some time to truly win over shoppers again.

"Our objective is to take our position of trust greater than the rest of the market and well above our starting place," he said.

Part of that effort will involve doubling the amount of British food Sainsbury's buys by 2020 compared to 2010. King said the chain was already well ahead of rivals and had increased the amount of British food it bought by 50% since 2007.

He added: "We will continue to invest in further quality control. You may think you've got the best security systems but that doesn't mean you can't dust yourself down and do a little more."

King will not be around to see that promise through. He remains in day to day control of Sainsbury's only while his replacement Mike Coupe prepares to take on the baton in July.

But King said he still had "no idea" what he was going to do when he leaves the company this summer, appearing to suggest his son was a more likely new recruit for motorsport's Formula 1, where he is widely rumoured to be set to replace current boss Bernie Ecclestone.

He said: "There's no vacancy. My interest in motorsport is because my son is a fantastic racing driver, he is the British Formula 3 Champion and I am proud of his achievement. If he reaches Formula 1 that would be my proudest moment."

The former Mars, Asda and Marks & Spencer executive repeated his assertion that he wanted "one more big job" but appeared to give himself a broad sweep: "My background is at public companies at Sainsbury's and in food more widely, I've worked for retailers and manufacturers and I'm sure there are other opportunities out there."

webTitle: EC raises eurozone growth forecasts; FTSE 100 drops back from 14-year high – as it happened

fields.standfirst:
EC predicts euro GDP will increase by 1.2% this year, while inflation will be just 1%

  • CLOSING SUMMARY
  • EC issues new economic forecasts
  • Chinese market slides...
  • ...Australia hit 5 1/2 year high
  • Ukraine’s currency hits record low
fields.body:
6.16pm GMT

Closing summary

And that’s all for today. A quick reminder of the key points.

The EC has raised its growth forecasts for the eurozone this year, but warned that inflation will be significantly below the ECB’s target in 2014 and 2015. Highlights start here.

It now expects the UK to grow faster too -- by 2.5% this year.

Vice-president Olli Rehn said a modest recovery was underway, but joblessness was still too high.

Fears over a clampdown on bank lending in China sent mining stocks falling in London, knocking 0.5% off the FTSE 100. Earlier the Shanghai stock market had suffered its biggest fall in seven months.

The Chinese yuan has weakened, fuelling speculation that the country’s central bank is preparing the ground for fresh reforms next week.

In the UK, retail sales staged a recovery.

While mortgage lending rallied, while business lending fell again.

And the world of Bitcoin is in crisis after a major exchange vanished -- and here’s some analysis.

Back tomorrow. Thanks and goodnight. GW

6.06pm GMT

Closing summary: FTSE 100 finishes in the red

The FTSE 100’s assault on its 1999 record high will have to wait another day, with the blue chip index finishing down 35 points at 6830, down over 0.5%.

Mining stocks were hit by fears of more turbulence in China (see earlier in the blog), with several major resource companies falling at least 2%.

Alastair McCaig, Market Analyst, IG, sums it up:

The index has given back almost all of the ground it made yesterday when it climbed towards its highest close for 13 years, as the heady highs of 1999 appear to have been too much for most traders.

Here’s the biggest fallers on the FTSE 100:

Other European markets closed pretty flat, with the German DAX and French CAC each dropping 0.1%, the Italian FTSE MIB down a whisker at 0.01%.

Spain’s IBEX jumped 0.5%.

5.57pm GMT

Over in Cyprus, striking electricity workers have reportedly caused power outages today in protest at plans to privatise the country’s power utility firm. More here.

5.38pm GMT

Great post from Alex Hern, one of our technology reporters, on how the Mt.Gox bitcoin exchange was brought down - and what the crypo-currency needs to do now to survive:

Mt.Gox v Fort Knox: What happens when a bitcoin exchange collapses

5.13pm GMT

Today’s EC growth forecasts have been hailed by our friends at the Daily Telegraph, as they show the UK growing rather faster than major European rivals.

The EC now expects UK GDP to rise by 2.5% this year, up from 2.2% -- much stronger than Germany’s forecast of 1.8%, or France’s 1.0% (see earlier in the blog for full details).

Szu Ping Chan writes:

Despite signs of a broader and “stronger” recovery, the Commission warned growth would remain reliant on private consumption, which could “decline sizeably” if eventual interest rate rises force more borrowers to curb spending to pay off their loans.

“Growth is likely to continue to come almost exclusively from domestic demand ... and investment playing a more important role as time progresses,” the Commission said. “[However] the upturn in investment may fail to materialise and private consumption may decline sizeably, as a result of continued weak wage growth, interest rate rises or the household debt burden weighing down on spending.”

More here.

4.55pm GMT

Economist Paul De Grauwe suggests we shouldn’t read too much into today’s EC forecasts....

Or ‘revised’, in economics lingo.

4.51pm GMT

Yuan weak currency; two theories:

Mark Williams of Capital Economics argues that the surprise weakness of the Chinese renminbi in recent days shows that its central bank is plotting something:

The People’s Bank of China (PBC) has engineered an abrupt fall in the renminbi over the past week or so (see chart above).

Its immediate aim appears to be to shift market expectations of continued, steady appreciation against the dollar. But the unusual (for the renminbi) scale of the decline may also signal a broader shift in policy stance.

Over the past few years, with the renminbi widely seen as undervalued, China’s primary line of defence against speculative inflows has been its capital controls. Recently though, the PBC has come to the view that the renminbi is close to its “fair” market value. It believes in turn that a key constraint on opening up the capital account has been lifted. The main remaining barrier, in the PBC’s eyes, is the engrained (but, it feels, unjustified) market expectation that the renminbi will appreciate which fuels speculative inflows. A period of greater market volatility lies ahead as the PBC attempts to reset that view.

Whether this works will depend ultimately on whether speculative flows are the main remaining source of upward pressure on the renminbi. We don’t think they are. China’s current account surplus remains large and looks likely to grow. The healthy returns on funds invested in China are still attracting more capital to the country than is going overseas. As a result, we continue to expect further exchange rate appreciation this year along with substantial foreign exchange accumulation. But investors should be prepared for greater volatility along the way.

However, Alphaville’s Izabella Kaminska has another theory: that Chinese firms had, until recently, been trying to make a quick profit by borrowing US dollars, converting it into yuan, buying domestic debt, and planning to cash in by reversing the trade once the yuan had strengthened, as seemed inevitable.

That trade could now be unravelling, she suggests, if there simply aren’t enough US dollars available (as capital flows back to the US).

More here: The curious incident of the PBOC in the USDCNY market

4.33pm GMT

The Open Europe thinktank has published a research note on today’s EC winter forecasts.

Here’s some highlights:

Inflation forecast cut

A metric which everyone is watching at the moment is inflation. As we have discussed before, March has been pegged as a key meeting for the ECB and is expected to be a defining choice over whether the bank takes more action to tackle inflation. The EC has cut its forecast for inflation from 1.5% to 1.1% for this year while last year’s has been revised to 1.3% from 1.5%. Despite the language being quite strong on inflation remaining low and subdued, these forecasts aren’t far from the ECB’s own and are unlikely to push them one way or another when it comes to taking further action. The graph also highlights that the view of core inflation (without energy or food prices) been on a slow decline for some time but is expected to melt upwards over the coming years. Again this fits with current ECB thinking rather than bucking against it.

Spain and Italy – diverging forecasts, but plenty of common problems

One of the more surprising points is that Spain has got the most substantial upgrade of all the big eurozone countries – with its 2014 growth forecast raised from +0.5% to +1%. At the same time Italy is the only big eurozone country whose growth forecast for this year has been revised downwards – from +0.7% to +0.6%. Similarly, on the unemployment side (while Spain remains in a much worse position) the forecast has improved somewhat for Spain and worsened for Italy. In any case, both continue to struggle with their large debt loads (more below), although new Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi might take the less than optimistic forecast as an important reminder of the reforms he needs to pursue, not unlike the ones Spain has undertaken…

Debt remains a problem in the eurozone

By 2015, seven eurozone countries are forecast to have public debt levels above 100% of GDP – Belgium, Ireland, Cyprus, Greece, Spain, Italy and Portugal. As the report warns, this debt overhang could become a drag on medium term growth, particularly when combined with other factors such as the knock on effects of years of depressed investment, high unemployment and falling productivity.

The full note is here: The European Commission’s new economic forecasts: Fragile recovery continues, but problems remain

4.25pm GMT

The FTSE 100 is still in the red as trading comes towards a close, down 35 points or 0.5% at 6811.

Mining stocks continue to drag the market down, as investors fear a sharp slowdown in China as banking lending is tightened. Fresnillo is down 3.2%, followed by Rio Tinto (-2.8%), Anglo American (-2.3%) and Antofagasta (-2.2%).

Michael Hewson of CMC Markets blames the selloff on the surprise drop in the yuan today, which many analysts believe means the People’s Bank of China is softening up the markets for new economic reforms next week.

He writes:

Nothing sums up the fickle nature of equity markets more than today’s market reaction to the very same events that we knew about yesterday morning, and the concerns being expressed about Chinese bank lending and possible future steps that Chinese authorities might take in seeking to take some of the heat out of the property market. The catalyst on this occasion appears to have been further sharp falls in the Chinese currency while Chinese stock markets dropped back near to multi month lows.

Wall Street, though, is pretty flat. Hewson again:

While European markets appear to have taken fright from the dive in Chinese markets it would appear that US markets are much less concerned opening slightly lower after the record highs posted on the S&P500 yesterday.

Stocks in focus include JP Morgan who announced that they would be cutting thousands of more jobs in addition to the 13,000 already announced due to plunging demand for home loans, which raises concerns about the longer term health of the US housing market.

Also in focus DIY retailer Home Depot opened higher after their latest earnings report beat market expectations, coming in at $0.73c a share, though we could well see any gains tempered by the fact that the outlook for 2014 was adjusted lower.

Updated at 4.25pm GMT

3.56pm GMT

LSE student and economic history ace Simon Hinrichsen tweets a couple of interesting charts on the possibility of Ukraine defaulting, from Japanese bank Nomura.

3.16pm GMT

Ever wondered how long you’d have to toil at the coal face until you’ve earned as much as a top banker?

Well, now you can find out. My colleague Chris Fenn has taken HSBC’s latest financial results, from yesterday, and put the salaries of its eight most highly-paid staff into context:

It’s here: How long would you have to work to earn a banker’s yearly wage?

I’ve popped the average UK salary in, as an example:

3.08pm GMT

Lots more Tesco convenience stores, coming to high streets near you....

The supermarket chain has been briefing analysts on its new strategy (see 12.23pm) - and promised an extra £200m on price cuts in the UK:

3.00pm GMT

Wall Street is open, and the main indices are down in early trading.

The Dow Jones industrial average has lost 52 points, or 0.3%, to 16154.

The S&P 500, which hit an all-time high yesterday, has dropped 1.8 points or 0.1% to 1845.

Ramin Nakisa, a global macro strategist at UBS, sounds confident that the US market will be benefit from turbulence in the emerging markets, telling Reuters that:

“We think there will be further flows into the U.S. as the Fed cuts back on its stimulus.

“If you could earn 3-3.5 percent on U.S. Treasuries for example would you risk money in volatile emerging market debt for a small premium.”

US Treasuries (government debt) have risen in value, pushing the yield (interest rate) on 10-year bonds down to 2.70% from 2.74% yesterday.

2.20pm GMT

2.19pm GMT

Over to America, where the S&P/Case Shiller index shows that house prices in 20 US metro areas rose by 0.8% in December, on a seasonally adjusted basis.

That’s a faster rate than analysts expected, but a slight slowdown compared with November’s 0.9% growth.

Annually, prices were up 13.4% compared with a year ago -- the best December reading in eight years.

David M. Blitzer, chairman of the Index Committee at S&P Dow Jones Indices, cautioned that the housing recovery may be slowing:

The S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Index ended its best year since 2005...

However, gains are slowing from month-to-month and the strongest part of the recovery in home values may be over.

1.48pm GMT

Luke Baker, Reuters’ top man in Brussels, explains why the EC supports a donors’ conference for Ukraine:

1.47pm GMT

Olli Rehn: A modest recovery is gaining ground

Here’s the top line from EC vice-president Olli Rehn today, arguing the eurozone recovery is gathering pace:

Recovery is gaining ground in Europe, following the return to growth in the middle of last year.

The strengthening of domestic demand this year should help us to achieve more balanced and sustainable growth. Rebalancing of the European economy has been progressing and external competitiveness is improving, particularly in the most vulnerable countries. The worst of the crisis may now be behind us, but this is not an invitation to be complacent, as the recovery is still modest.

To make the recovery stronger and create more jobs, we need to stay the course of economic reform.

And today’s winter forecasts (see here onwards) also shows that government deficits are expected to keep falling -- to 2.7% of GDP in the EU and 2.6% in the euro area.

That will push total debt-to-GDP ratios to almost 90% in the EU and 96% in the euro area.

1.42pm GMT

Rehn: I'd support a donors' conference for Ukraine

The final question at the EC winter forecasts press conference was on the Ukraine crisis.

Olli Rehn said the Commisison was in close contact with the IMF on the issue. He said Kiev will need short-term funding help, and longer-term financial aid to fund economic reforms and recovery.

Rehn added that he would support the idea of a ‘donors’ conference’ for Ukraine, where EU member states with the most resources could agree contributions to help Ukraine.

He pointed out that most of the EU’s resources in an issue such as this reside with its member states (as there isn’t a particular EU budget or pool of money to tap).

1.37pm GMT

webTitle: McColl's stock market flotation fails to soar

fields.standfirst: Convenience store chain's IPO values 1,276 branches at £200m, short of the £225m valuation it was thought to want
fields.body:
McColl's stock market flotation has fallen short of the valuation the convenience store chain had hoped for, potentially cutting millions of pounds from payouts for the founder and other senior executives.

The company set the price for its initial public offering at 191p a share, valuing the network of 1,276 shops at about £200m – but when McColl's announced the sale last month it was understood to be seeking a market value of about £225m.

The price cut will substantially reduce the payday for McColl's top managers, including chairman and chief executive James Lancaster, who founded the group as a cigarette vending machine business in 1973. Lancaster's 28% stake will be worth £56m compared with £63m he would have received at the original expected asking price. The finance director, Jonathan Miller's stake is the same size while the chief operating officer, Martyn Aguss's will be worth £14m instead of £15.75m.

But Lancaster said the offer, which was oversubscribed with investors, was a vote of confidence in the business's growth prospects.

"We are delighted with the strong interest that we have seen from investors in McColl's. It will enable us to accelerate our growth strategy, further enhancing our position in a rapidly growing convenience market."

The company, which trades as RS McColl and Martin's, is now second only to Tesco in convenience retail.

Retail analyst Nick Bubb said he had thought the mooted £225m valuation for McColl's was on the low side but that the market appeared underwhelmed.

"Maybe investors were more excited by the other retailing IPOs coming down the line," Bubb said.

McColl's float on Friday will be the first retail IPO of 2014, a year when many retailers, including online seller Appliances Online hope to take advantage of booming stock markets and a revival in consumer confidence to raise cash in the market. Pets at Home and Poundland have also announced their intention to float soon.

The McColl's float will raise £133m comprising an initial £50m to pay off pricey debt and convert newsagents into food stores and a further £83m when current shareholders sell parts of their stakes.

On top of the 80% owned by Lancaster and other employees, 20% of the company is owned by Cavendish Square Partners. The fund contains a mixed bag of company stakes from HBOS's ill-starred foray into private equity. Cavendish is 30% owned by Lloyds Banking Group, which rescued HBOS during the financial crisis.

webTitle: CBI retail sales better than expected

fields.standfirst: Large majority of retailers say sales volumes will grow at a robust pace next month, with only 15% expecting sales to fall
fields.body:
Shoppers have braved the wind and rain that struck Britain in recent weeks to register better than expected retail sales last month, according to the CBI's latest survey of the sector.

A large majority of retailers said sales volumes would grow at a robust pace next month, with only 15% saying they expect sales to fall. The return of more buoyant sales next month comes after official figures showed a dip in January that sparked fears of a post-Christmas slowdown.

The CBI said 45% of respondents reported that sales volumes last month were up on a year ago, while 8% said they were down, giving a balance of +37%, the strongest since June 2012 and easily beating City expectations of a figure no better than +15%. The survey took place between 23 January and 12 February.

Most sectors of the retail trade saw growth, with shops selling goods linked to the housing market performing markedly better than a year ago. Furniture and carpet stores, which until last spring had suffered four hard years of falling sales, saw a particularly strong recovery.

More firms also said they planned to increase investment than said they would freeze or cut it, adding to the positive outlook. The only blot on the survey's results was a cut in employment fore the first time in a year.

Barry Williams, Asda's chief merchandising officer for food and chair of the CBI distributive trades survey panel, said: "The high streets have kicked on once again this month, with growth the strongest since the summer of 2012.

"There is growth across many sectors, including grocers and clothing outlets, while investment intentions are at their highest for more than three years. Although we are by no means seeing a universally confident shopper, the positive indicators have perhaps given some people the urge to spend."

Richard Lowe, head of retail and wholesale at Barclays, said the situation would improve further as the weather becomes milder over the next couple of months. "Retailers will be hoping consumers will continue to hit the high street and online to make fresh purchases for their homes and wardrobes," he said.

But Howard Archer, chief UK economist at IHS Global Insight, warned that the 4.5% gains in sales made year on year will be difficult to sustain without a recovery in wages.

"Consumer spending is clearly being supported by elevated confidence, markedly higher employment and the substantially improving housing market. In addition, the squeeze on purchasing power is gradually easing due to lower inflation.

He said: "Even so, the upside for consumer spending is likely to remain capped for some time to come. Consumers have faced a prolonged squeeze on their purchasing power, and this is currently easing only gradually even though consumer price inflation has come down to a 50-month low of 1.9% in January. This is because annual earnings growth is only slowly picking up and was still limited to 1.1% in the three months to December."

webTitle: Persimmon profits surge as Help to Buy scheme fuels demand

fields.standfirst: Britain's second biggest housebuilder says annual underlying pre-tax profits rose 49%, with sale completions up 16%
fields.body:
Britain's second biggest housebuilder has announced a surge in annual profit after the government's Help to Buy scheme helped fuel demand for new homes and revive Britain's property market.

Persimmon said underlying pre-tax profit jumped 49% to £330m in the year to the end of December – near the top of City forecasts. The first few weeks of this year's crucial spring selling season went well, it added, as Britain.

The company said sale completions rose by 16% to 11,528 and the average selling price increased 4% to £181,861. Forward sales, which are agreed but not completed, rose 41% to £1.4bn.

Persimmon's strong results follow similarly buoyant figures from Bovis Homes yesterday as housebuilders reap the rewards of less stringent lending by banks and rising house prices. More listed housebuilders – Taylor Wimpey, Barratt and Redrow – report later this week.

As a result of booming business, Persimmon said it would return cash to shareholders more quickly than planned. It will pay out a dividend of 70p in July this year with further early payments in 2016 and 2018 that would originally have been paid in 2021.

Britain's housebuilders have been the main beneficiaries of government schemes to unblock the mortgage market. Help to Buy, introduced by the chancellor last year, underwrites part of a buyer's mortgage and has increased the number of purchases and improved confidence among buyers and builders.

However, some economists have warned that Help to Buy is stoking a pre-election housing bubble and that firing up the property market repeats the mistakes made before the financial crisis. Campaigners have also accused the scheme of pricing out more potential buyers than it has helped by spurring a frenzy in the housing market.

Nicholas Wrigley, Persimmon's chairman, said: "Persimmon achieved a strong result for the year as we responded quickly to the increased customer demand that resulted from improved mortgage lending, the introduction of Help to Buy in April 2013 and the increase in consumer confidence as the UK returned to more meaningful economic growth.

"The group entered 2014 with a very strong forward order book and the early weeks of the spring selling season have been encouraging, with our weekly private sales rate per site being 22% ahead of last year for the first eight weeks.  We anticipate a further year of encouraging sales growth in 2014."

Persimmon said it had sold 4,250 new homes to customers using Help to Buy and that 2,203 of those legally completed in 2013.

Persimmon shares have risen almost 40% since the end of September. The shares were up 0.7% in morning trading to £14.81 – not far off a 52-week high of £15.08.

webTitle: Bank of England could raise interest rates next spring, says MPC member

fields.bodyText: A Bank of England policymaker has reinforced expectations that the first rise in interest rates will come as soon as next spring, in remarks that pushed up the pound. Ian McCafferty, a member of the monetary policy committee, said that market expectations that the Bank of England will start to raise rates in the second quarter of 2015 are "not unreasonable". He told news agency Reuters in an interview that wage deals in coming months would be "quite critical" as policymakers watch for inflation risks. Under governor Mark Carney, earlier this month the Bank overhauled its forward guidance policy on when rates would rise from their record low of 0.5%. At the time it said a view in markets that rates could rise in the second quarter of 2015 was consistent with its goal of keeping inflation close to the government-set 2% target. McCafferty told Reuters: "In that sense, you'd have to say that that market curve is not unreasonable. "The exact timing of course is going to depend on events that have yet to unfold in terms of how the recovery proceeds over the course of the next six to 12 months or so." Following his remarks being published, the pound rose to session highs against the dollar and euro. McCafferty, a former chief economic adviser to business group CBI, said he was watching for pressures on inflation from pay deals negotiated in coming months. After years above its target inflation has now fallen below 2%, to stand at 1.9% in January. "I suppose my view would be if anything, the risk I am watching for, because I think it fits with our mandate, is were we to see inflation risks or inflation behaviour start to develop," he said. "At the moment, that seems to be well under control. "If we did see some inflationary pressure – more than we currently expect in our central case – that would if anything, I suspect, lead the committee to consider slightly earlier rate rises." The policymaker said another factor to watch was the strength of the pound, which last week strengthened to a four-year high against the dollar. "Were it to continue to rise, I would get more worried," McCafferty said, and indicated further strengthening could delay a rate hike. "It's clearly a consideration in terms of total monetary conditions in the economy so we would need to take it into account when determining what the appropriate monetary stance would be going forward," he said.

fields.headline: Bank of England could raise interest rates next spring, says MPC member
fields.body:
A Bank of England policymaker has reinforced expectations that the first rise in interest rates will come as soon as next spring, in remarks that pushed up the pound.

Ian McCafferty, a member of the monetary policy committee, said that market expectations that the Bank of England will start to raise rates in the second quarter of 2015 are "not unreasonable". He told news agency Reuters in an interview that wage deals in coming months would be "quite critical" as policymakers watch for inflation risks.

Under governor Mark Carney, earlier this month the Bank overhauled its forward guidance policy on when rates would rise from their record low of 0.5%. At the time it said a view in markets that rates could rise in the second quarter of 2015 was consistent with its goal of keeping inflation close to the government-set 2% target. McCafferty told Reuters: "In that sense, you'd have to say that that market curve is not unreasonable.

"The exact timing of course is going to depend on events that have yet to unfold in terms of how the recovery proceeds over the course of the next six to 12 months or so."

Following his remarks being published, the pound rose to session highs against the dollar and euro.

McCafferty, a former chief economic adviser to business group CBI, said he was watching for pressures on inflation from pay deals negotiated in coming months. After years above its target inflation has now fallen below 2%, to stand at 1.9% in January.

"I suppose my view would be if anything, the risk I am watching for, because I think it fits with our mandate, is were we to see inflation risks or inflation behaviour start to develop," he said. "At the moment, that seems to be well under control.

"If we did see some inflationary pressure – more than we currently expect in our central case – that would if anything, I suspect, lead the committee to consider slightly earlier rate rises."

The policymaker said another factor to watch was the strength of the pound, which last week strengthened to a four-year high against the dollar.

"Were it to continue to rise, I would get more worried," McCafferty said, and indicated further strengthening could delay a rate hike.

"It's clearly a consideration in terms of total monetary conditions in the economy so we would need to take it into account when determining what the appropriate monetary stance would be going forward," he said.
fields.trailText: MPC member Ian McCafferty says market expectations rates could rise in the second quarter of 2015 are 'not unreasonable'

webTitle: Ladbrokes warns of falling profits as racing and football favourites win out

fields.standfirst: Bookmaker's net revenue down by £11m so far this year as 2013 results show operating profit down by a third
fields.body:
Ladbrokes has warned of a fall in first-half profits after customers proved luckier than Britain's second-largest bookmaker since the start of the year and the benefits of an upgrade to its digital business were delayed.

Ladbrokes said its net revenue was down by about £11m so far this year, with wet weather favouring the favourites in horse racing and the big teams performing well in the Premier League and FA Cup. The gloomy outlook statement accompanied annual results that showed operating profit down by nearly a third.

Ladbrokes is also struggling to catch up with competitors in online gambling. Last year it signed an agreement with Playtech, the Israeli company that had transformed rival William Hill's digital service.

However, the partnership has proved more disruptive to Ladbrokes' business than expected and the predicted gains have not yet materialised.

Group operating profit fell 32.9% to £138.3m for the year to 31 December but pre-tax profit, including exceptional costs of £51.6m, mainly for switching to Playtech systems, fell by two-thirds to £67.6m. The annual dividend will be unchanged at 8.9p a share.

Richard Glynn, Ladbrokes' chief executive, said: "While our financial results for 2013 were disappointing, we made real operational progress which has continued into this year. We remain confident about the direction of the business and the momentum we are creating."

Glynn is under pressure after his plan to revamp Ladbrokes faltered last year, resulting in a string of profit warnings before the latest downbeat forecast. The company is in a race to get its online business up to scratch so that customers can bet easily on mobile phones and tablets before the bonanza of the football World Cup, which kicks off in July.

Ladbrokes said it expected to close between 40 and 50 shops this year because of rising operating costs and higher rents as the economy recovers.

The betting industry also faces political pressure over its reliance on fixed-odds gambling machines. Britain's biggest bookies have launched a code of conduct including letting customers set a maximum loss before betting on what has been called the "crack cocaine" of gambling.

Ladbrokes shares have lost about 38% of their value since the Playtech deal was announced last March even as the wider stock market has boomed. The shares were down 1.8% to 148.4p in early trading.

webTitle: Qantas help would fly in face of 'age of entitlement', warns Coalition MP

fields.standfirst: Queensland MP Teresa Gambaro says government cannot bail out companies who are victims of their own poor performance
fields.body:
A Liberal backbencher has warned the government a plan to offer Qantas a government-backed debt guarantee unavailable to its main competitor, Virgin, would be unfair, contrary to the Coalition’s aim of ending the “age of entitlement” and would risk turning the national carrier from an “800-pound gorilla” into “Godzilla.”

Queensland backbencher Teresa Gambaro has told colleagues at a closed-door joint party briefing that if the government wanted to declare an end to the “age of entitlement” it had to be consistent about it.

“If our message to the nation is that the age of entitlement is over and if we’re asking the people of Australia to live within their means, then that same yardstick must be applied to corporate Australia as well. We must be consistent … we cannot continue to bail out companies who are the victims first and foremost of their own poor performance – we would effectively be rewarding bad behaviour,” she said.

“In relation to the prospect of providing a debt facility for Qantas, if we are going to provide such a facility, then we should do so equitably across the airline industry in this country. We must not play favourites … I am very concerned as to what the impact of a debt facility extended just to Qantas would be on Virgin Australia, which is headquartered in my electorate of Brisbane.”

Her comments came as the government considers exactly such a debt guarantee for Qantas.

The main alternative means to help the struggling airline – legislation to change the Qantas Sales Act to allow more than 49% foreign ownership – is destined to fail.

The treasurer, Joe Hockey, has previously called Virgin a “3,000-pound gorilla” because it is backed by foreign governments.

Qantas is widely expected to announce thousands of job losses when it announces its half-yearly results on Thursday. It has refused to confirm reported job loss figures ranging from 3,000 to 5,000, but has said “tough decisions’’ will be necessary to achieve $2bn in savings.

Unions fear Qantas is preparing to sack at least 3000 workers and then re-employ them through company-controlled labour hire firms and subsidiaries on lower wages and conditions, as part of a deal to win federal government assistance.

The transport minister, Warren Truss, has confirmed he is drafting legislation to “take away’’ the “legislative shackles” imposed by the Qantas Sale Act, which caps the company’s foreign ownership at 49%.

But the Labor party and the Greens have ruled out support for the amendment in the Senate, meaning it could not pass parliament before the new Senate sits in July. And Clive Palmer, whose Palmer United party senators will hold crucial crossbench votes after July, has also ruled out supporting the change.

The Labor leader, Bill Shorten, restated his party’s opposition to the change on Tuesday, saying Labor did not think the government should “hand away a national icon to foreign governments” and allow thousands of jobs to be sent offshore.

Given the likely failure of the sales act changes, the government could offer Qantas a “standby” or emergency debt guarantee after two ratings agencies downgraded its credit rating to “junk” status. The move would not require legislation.

Tony Abbott again warned on Tuesday the airline had to “get their own house in order” before asking for such help, but said the sales act did mean it was “competing with a ball and chain” weighing it down.

The government guarantee could mean ratings agencies would classify the airline as a government-related entity, allowing it to regain an investment-grade credit rating and reducing the cost of its borrowings. But should the airline ever call on the guarantee it would be required to pay a substantial fee.

Virgin has reacted angrily to the proposal, saying it would immediately ask the government for the same deal as anything offered to Qantas.

Sir Richard Branson, the founder of the Virgin Group, has criticised both Qantas and the government, claiming that any taxpayer assistance for the beleaguered airline would deter businesses from investing in Australia.

In a full-page advertisement published in News Corporation newspapers, Branson said if the government provided financial help for Qantas, it would “severely damage competition in Australia, encourage others to ask for handouts and companies worldwide would think twice before investing in Australia.”

Virgin Australia’s chief executive, John Borghetti, said Qantas was “looking for a free ride” and claimed it was a bit “rich” for Hockey to accuse his airline of being the biggest market player.

“Let’s look at the facts: Qantas is three to four times bigger than us; it has hundreds and hundreds of millions, in fact it’s got almost $3bn in cash,” he said.

“It has dominant positions in every single sector of the domestic market; it is hellbent, and by their own words by the way, of adding two aircraft for every aircraft that we add irrespective, irrespective of the financial outcome, so I think it’s a bit rich turning that around,” he said last week.

Gambaro made similar arguments to the joint party meeting. Her Liberal colleague Warren Entsch complained Qantas had been mismanaged.

In a speech to Coalition backbenchers earlier this month, the Qantas CEO, Alan Joyce, argued he was not asking for an unfair handout.

“We have never asked for a handout. And we are not asking for one now … The Qantas Sale Act limits our financial options, it adds cost to our business and it influences our actions as a publicly listed company. Over the long term, repealing it is essential to remove the distortions in our aviation system. However, we recognise there is little political and community appetite for changing the act in the short term,” he said.

In January Qantas “axed” flights to Tasmania and 35 jobs at Hobart airport, with the routes taken up by Qantas regional brand QantasLink, which immediately began to recruit new ground-handling staff.

In a statement at the time, Qantas said the overall level of direct and indirect employment in Tasmania would increase.
